verses.text: Hezekiah became king when he was twenty-five years old, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-nine years. His mother's name was Abijah daughter of Zechariah.
verses.comment: Names and reign lengths maintained as per Masoretic text; minor variants in some traditions.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, just as his ancestor David had done.
verses.comment: Hezekiah's faithfulness compared to David, consistent with Hebrew wording.

verses.text: In the first month of the first year of his reign, he opened the doors of the LORD’s house and repaired them.
verses.comment: First actions as king—temple restoration.

verses.text: He brought in the priests and Levites, assembled them in the eastern square,
verses.comment: Eastern square: location outside the temple.

verses.text: and said to them: "Listen to me, Levites! Now consecrate yourselves and consecrate the house of the LORD, the God of your ancestors, and remove the impurity from the holy place.
verses.comment: Direct command to sanctify themselves and the temple.

verses.text: For our fathers acted unfaithfully, did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD our God, and abandoned him. They turned their faces away from the LORD’s dwelling and turned their backs.
verses.comment: Turning away—literally 'turned their backs.'

verses.text: They also shut the doors of the vestibule, put out the lamps, did not burn incense, and did not offer burnt offerings in the holy place to the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Describes temple neglect.

verses.text: Therefore the wrath of the LORD came on Judah and Jerusalem, and he has made them an object of horror, astonishment, and mocking, as you see with your own eyes.
verses.comment: Standard terms for divine judgment used.

verses.text: Our fathers have fallen by the sword, and our sons, daughters, and wives are in captivity because of this.
verses.comment: Refers to previous judgment; captivity means exile/slavery.

verses.text: Now, it is in my heart to make a covenant with the LORD, the God of Israel, so that his fierce anger will turn away from us.
verses.comment: Making covenant echoes ancient renewal rituals.

verses.text: My sons, do not now be negligent, for the LORD has chosen you to stand before him, to serve him, to minister to him, and to burn incense.
verses.comment: Levites called to minister as chosen priests.

verses.text: Then the Levites arose: Mahath son of Amasai and Joel son of Azariah, from the Kohathites; Kish son of Abdi and Azariah son of Jehallelel, from the Merarites;
verses.comment: List of Levite leaders by clan.

verses.text: Johah son of Zimmah and Eden son of Joah, from the Gershonites;
verses.comment: Continues listing according to Levite groups.

verses.text: Shimri and Jeuel, from the descendants of Elizaphan; Zechariah and Mattaniah, from the descendants of Asaph;
verses.comment: Genealogical details preserved.

verses.text: Jehiel and Shimei, from the descendants of Heman; Shemaiah and Uzziel, from the descendants of Jeduthun.
verses.comment: Names and lineages preserved.

verses.text: They gathered their brothers, consecrated themselves, and went in, as the king had commanded by the words of the LORD, to cleanse the LORD’s house.
verses.comment: Obedience as per royal and divine instruction.

verses.text: The priests entered the inner part of the LORD’s house to cleanse it, and brought out all the impurity that they found in the temple of the LORD into the court of the house of the LORD. The Levites took it out and carried it to the Kidron Valley.
verses.comment: The Kidron Valley used for desecrated objects.

verses.text: They finished cleansing the whole house of the LORD, the altar of burnt offering, and all its utensils and the table for the bread of the Presence and all its utensils.
verses.comment: Specifies areas/objects consecrated.

verses.text: All the utensils which King Ahaz had thrown away during his reign in his unfaithfulness, we have prepared and sanctified. They are now before the altar of the LORD.
verses.comment: Restoration of previously desecrated objects.

verses.text: Hezekiah the king rose early, gathered the city officials, and went up to the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Emphasizes promptness and leadership.

verses.text: They brought seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs, and seven male goats for a sin offering for the kingdom, the sanctuary, and Judah. Hezekiah commanded the priests, the sons of Aaron, to offer them on the altar of the LORD.
verses.comment: Numbers of animals as symbolic completeness (seven).

verses.text: So they slaughtered the bulls, and the priests took the blood and sprinkled it on the altar. Then they slaughtered the rams and sprinkled their blood on the altar; likewise they slaughtered the lambs and sprinkled their blood on the altar.
verses.comment: Ritual actions as prescribed in Torah.

verses.text: Then they brought the male goats for the sin offering before the king and the assembly, and they laid their hands on them.
verses.comment: Laying on hands signifies identification/confession.

verses.text: The priests slaughtered them and made a sin offering with their blood on the altar, to make atonement for all Israel, as the king had commanded, since the burnt offering and the sin offering were for all Israel.
verses.comment: Atonement on behalf of entire nation.

verses.text: Hezekiah stationed the Levites in the LORD’s house with cymbals, harps, and lyres, as David, Gad the king’s seer, and Nathan the prophet had commanded, for this was the command of the LORD through his prophets.
verses.comment: Musical worship takes up Davidic tradition.

verses.text: The Levites stood with the instruments of David, and the priests with the trumpets.
verses.comment: Distinct roles in musical service maintained.

verses.text: Hezekiah commanded to offer the burnt offering on the altar. And as the burnt offering began, the song to the LORD began, with the trumpets and the instruments of David, king of Israel.
verses.comment: Sacrifice and worship commenced together as prescribed.

verses.text: All the assembly worshipped, the singers sang, and the trumpeters sounded. All this continued until the burnt offering was finished.
verses.comment: Synchronicity of sacrifice and worship preserved.

verses.text: When the offering ended, the king and all who were present with him bowed themselves and worshipped.
verses.comment: Action of prostration after sacrifice maintained.

verses.text: King Hezekiah and the officials told the Levites to sing praises to the LORD with the words of David and of Asaph the seer. So they sang praises with joy, bowed down, and worshipped.
verses.comment: Songs attributed to David and Asaph; joy and worship.

verses.text: Then Hezekiah said, "You have now dedicated yourselves to the LORD. Come near, bring sacrifices and thank offerings to the house of the LORD." So the assembly brought sacrifices and thank offerings, and all whose hearts were willing brought burnt offerings.
verses.comment: Freewill offerings specified per original Hebrew.

verses.text: The number of burnt offerings the assembly brought was seventy bulls, one hundred rams, and two hundred lambs— all these as burnt offerings to the LORD.
verses.comment: Specific numbers match original accounts.

verses.text: And the consecrated offerings were six hundred bulls and three thousand sheep.
verses.comment: Large numbers indicate national participation.

verses.text: But the priests were too few and could not skin all the burnt offerings, so their brothers the Levites helped them, until the work was finished and the priests had consecrated themselves— for the Levites had been more diligent to consecrate themselves than the priests.
verses.comment: Levites aiding priests—emphasizes ritual urgency.

verses.text: Burnt offerings were abundant, along with the fat of the peace offerings and with the drink offerings for the burnt offerings. Thus the service of the LORD’s house was restored.
verses.comment: Mentions restoration of ritual order.

verses.text: Hezekiah and all the people rejoiced, because God had prepared the people, for the thing happened suddenly.
verses.comment: Celebration at God's swift restoration; 'suddenly' means with unexpected speed.
